article_title: Effect of president's immigration action on Texas unclear
article_text: To continue reading this story, you will need to be a digital subscriber to HoustonChronicle.com.

article_metadata.description: AUSTIN - Amid Democratic jubilation and Republican outrage, Texas officials facing the more practical question of how President Barack Obama's new immigration plan would affect government programs found few clear answers Friday.  Officials at a dozen state and local agencies said they were scrambling to study Obama's order temporarily shielding up to 5 million illegal immigrants from deportation, including an estimated 700,000 in Texas and 130,000 in the Houston area, but the biggest potential consequences were indirect and uncertain.  Illegal immigrants are eligible to receive few social services in Texas and the executive action will not change that, officials said, although removing the fear of deportation could lead some to seek Medicaid and other benefits for children born here who already qualify for help.  [...] because Texas does not have an income tax, its budget would only get a boost if the president's action leads more people here illegally to find work, make money and buy products subject to the sales tax.  A spokesman declined to provide more information about the legal challenge Abbott announced Thursday night in a news release that said Obama had "bypassed the will of the American people, eroding the very foundation of our nation's Constitution and bestowing a legacy of lawlessness."  Obama's plan, which he said during a televised addressed Thursday night would ensure the United States is deporting dangerous criminals and not those trying to make an honest living in the country, is centered on a legal reprieve for up to 4 million illegal immigrants who are the parents of American citizens, and who agree to pay taxes, pass a background check and meet other requirements, according to the White House.  [...] the order would not change eligibility for state services such as Medicaid, food stamps or welfare, said Linda Edwards Gockel of the Health and Human Services Commission.  According to the state, the cost of providing emergency care for non-citizens in Texas totaled $345 million last year.
article_metadata.author.name: By Brian M. Rosenthal and Patrick Svitek
